awd_titl_txt: Improving Access to Coordinated Archaeometric Services, Method Development and Post-Analysis Data Validation and Interpretation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Archaeology, Materials and Applied Spectroscopy (CAMAS) at Idaho State University provides analytical elemental, isotopic and micro-scale imaging tools to researchers in the archaeological, paleoenvironmental and geochemical sciences.
Since its inception in 2008, the center has completed analysis for over 400 novel research Projects: these include faculty and student researchers at ISU, national and international academic research collaborations and fee-based contract analysis. This award will provide support to upgrade CAMAS' instrumentation and to make its services available to a wide range of researchers in archaeology and multiple other areas of research. The data thus collected, in addition to offering insight into past behaviors have the potential to address current day environmental issues by providing more precise characterizations of present day environments and setting these into an extended chronological framework. 

CAMAS has endeavored to position itself as a regionally-recognized archaeometry laboratory with disciplinary strengths in provenance analysis, paleoclimatic reconstruction and biomolecular archaeology. Implicit in this research mission is to make these technologies available to researchers regardless of their ability to pay for archaeometric services. CAMAS was envisioned as a user-based facility,meaning that individual researchers are encouraged to perform the instrumental analyses themselves and participate in data collection, reduction and interpretation under the mentoring of CAMAS staff and research personnel. Presently, CAMAS offsets the cost of subsidized analysis with fee-based contracts from research, governmental and commercial clientele. This award will increase the opportunities that CAMAS can provide to researchers, through acquisition of integrative technologies, initiation of a visiting researcher program and provision of training opportunities for graduate students to become expert users and interpreters of generated data. Funding will support analytical work with a broad range of materials, from archaeological lithics and ceramics, sediments and residues to bones and teeth, and will bring the expertise of archaeologists, geologists and forensic scientists to bear on the interpretation of analytical results. Specifically this award provides funding for equipment upgrade and maintenance (pXRF and SEM-EDS), acquisition of a compact, high-sensitivity FTIR, tools and reagents for constructing matrix-matched analytical standards, and a comprehensive visiting researcher program promoting subsidized analysis, research design, method development, and post-experiment data validation and archaeological interpretation.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Archaeology, Materials and Applied Spectroscopy completed activities under NSF BCS 1523409:  Improving Access to Coordinated Archaeometric Services, Method Development and Post-Analysis Data Validation and Interpretation on 07/31/2021. During the period of the award, CAMAS sponsored 16 visiting researcher projects and completed 68 sponsored research projects, the latter where data collection was performed by Idaho State University principle investigators, CAMAS staff and/or student research assistants. In both cases, project co-PIs provided essential services in the form of project development and scope, method development or implementation, and data validation and interpretation support. Projects sponsored under this award have to date resulted in:

  • 12 peer reviewed publications
  • Four manuscripts in preparation
  • 19 research or professional reports
  • 25+ conference presentations
  • 14 completed masters theses
  • 6 masters or doctoral theses in progress
  • One undergraduate honors thesis
  • Two NSF graduate research fellowship (one funded, one pending)
  • Two NSF post-doctoral research applications (not funded)

The primary goal of this project was to specifically increase the archaeometry opportunities that CAMAS can provide to researchers, through acquisition of integrative technologies, instantiation of a visiting researcher program and providing training opportunities for graduate students to become expert users and interpreters of generated archaeometric data. In this capacity we were generally successful, given that the lab experienced some offline periods, during the two moves the facility made under the award and the cessation of visiting researcher opportunities after fall 2019, due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. 

Major positive outcomes of this project were the number of visiting or sponsored research we were able to accommodate across a variety of sample types and analytical methods. Major classes of material we were able to analyze include 1) scanning electron microscopy of sedimentary and calculus-derived microfossils, or plant microremains, 2) IRMS stable isotope analysis of bone collagen and apatite, 3) laser ablation trace element analysis of biominerals, including bone, tooth, bivalve and eggshell, 4) laser ablation trace element analysis archaeological ceramic pastes, pigments and tempers, 5) thermal gravimetric analysis/differential thermal analysis of archaeological sediments and lithic materials, 6) laser ablation ICP-MS and portable x-ray fluorescence spectrometry (pXRF) provenance analysis and materials testing of regional obsidians for identifying and evaluating performance differences between sources.

Advances were made in methods for sample preparation and analysis with the goal of 1) improving the speed of preparation and specificity of analytical target, 2) developing methods to assess sample preservation prior to extensive preparation routines, and 3) preparing sample-specific standard materials for improved precision and matrix matching of laser ablation ICP-MS. Specifically, we were able to refine sampling strategies for serial sampling of tooth dentin using lab-made fixtures to isolate fragmentary and friable archaeological tooth and bone samples using serial sectioning and through acquisition of a hobby engraving machine coupled with a endoscopic camera and vacuum specimen collection, to replicate an out of production micro-milling device. These technical advancements were important for both visiting researcher and facilitated research projects. 

The award funded acquisition of an attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (ATR-FTIR), which we used to develop methods to evaluate preservation condition of approximately 700 bone and tooth samples prior to isotopic or DNA extraction. This evaluation strategy allowed researchers to prioritize specimens for sampling, permitting us to target those with the highest probability of positive result. We were also able to create and test new analytical standards for calibrating laser ablation ICP-MS samples, including a set of synthetic apatites for calibrating bone and tooth elemental acquisitions and aragonite standards for calibrating analyses on marine and lacustrine bivalves and other shell types.

Perhaps the most unanticipated outcome of this project was on the facilities that serve infrastructure. In support of the archaeological and forensic research performed in CAMAS, ISU moved the entirety of the instrumentation and support infrastructure into the Eames Advanced Technical Education and Innovations Complex in the Alvin Ricken Research Park. This enabled CAMAS access to significantly improved infrastructure, including full HEPA air filtration in all laboratory suites, on-site compressed gas generation, including air, nitrogen and oxygen, and upgraded power, air extraction/fume hoods. Currently, CAMAS occupies approximately 5,000 square feet of laboratory space, including wet/dirty sample preparation areas, a cold storage laboratory, dedicated laboratories with functional areas in 1) elemental and thermal analysis, 2) mass spectrometry, 3) electron and optical microscopy, 4) biomolecule and trace residue extraction, and 5) administrative/visiting researcher/student offices and conference rooms. All supporting infrastructure (vacuum pumps, chillers, gas generation, water filtration, backup power supplies) were relocated into dedicated mechanical corridors, permitting upgraded acoustic and environmental hygiene in laboratory spaces. CAMAS took on several additional pieces of primary instrumentation, including two new ICP-MS, thermal analysis MS, two transmission electron microscopes and 12 optical microscopes with CCD imagers and support computers.

We intend to continue the mission established under this award to offer archaeological/forensic analytical services to interested communities.
